Body:
Both Japanese and Korean are "topic-comment" languages and both have an explicit topic particle.

(I believe Chinese might be an example of a topic-comment language without a topic particle but I may be wrong.)

Which other languages have topic particles? Any well-known languages?
Title: How common is a topic particle beyond just Japanese and Korean?

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
I'm a grad student in linguistics, interested in semantics, pragmatics and prosody and currently doing fieldwork on K'iche' (a very cool Mayan language spoken in Guatemala).

Off the clock, I'm also interested in figuring out why the heck we teach this stuff — or in other words, why do people care about linguistics who don't do it for a living, what their interests are, and what they want to learn or get out of our classes. I figure if all goes well, I'll be teaching Intro to Linguistics once a year for the rest of my life, and I may as well get good at it.

OwnerUser.AboutMe:
Travelling armchair linguist.

Never studied in an institution but read books and web with probably more breadth than depth.

Always on the road surviving in a strange foreign language, currently Mongolian and Mandarin Chinese.

And I collect dictionaries.
